results.title: Shoppingtown
results.creator_credit: David Caesar, Peter Leovic and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Short Australian film by David Caesar which creates a portrait of Parramatta Shoppingtown in August 1986. Initial blank screen isolates people’s words as they voice their aspirations and understanding of happiness. Silence follows as a series of film portraits reveal the inhabitants of Shoppingtown, a shopping centre in suburban Sydney. A rapid montage of images and sounds, most prominently the sounds of the checkout scanner, denote the commercial aspect of a space which has been established in the film as communal and civic. The portraits of shoppers and mall dwellers return, ending in a portrait of the filmmakers themselves.
results.description: Short Australian film by David Caesar which creates a portrait of Parramatta Shoppingtown in August 1986. results.title: L'Arrivee = The Arrival
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description:
‘L’Arrivee’ is Tscherkassky’s second homage to the Lumiere-brothers. First you see the arrival of the film itself, which shows the arrival of a train at a station. But that train collides with a second train, causing a violent crash, which leads us to an unexpected third arrival, the arrival of a beautiful woman, the happy-end.

Reduced to two minutes, ‘L’Arrivee’ gives a brief, but exact summary of what cinematography (after its arrival with Lumieres train) has made into an enduring presence of our visual environment: violence, emotions. Or, as an anonymous American housewife (cited by T. W. Adorno) used to describe Hollywood’s version of life: ‘Getting into trouble and out of it again.’

results.title: Outer space
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. Sounds of crickets, static and distorted music give way to explosions, screams, and garbled voices. The actress’ face multiplies across the screen as the frame is invaded by sprocket holes, an optical soundtrack, and flashes of solarized imagery.
results.description: Prolific Austrian avant-garde filmmaker and theorist, Peter Tscherkassky, reinvents a 1981 Barbara Hershey horror vehicle, leaving the original’s crystalline surface intact only to violently shatter its narrative illusion. results.title: [Musterrolle: a compilation of short films by Peter Tscherkassky]
results.brief_description: 15 titles create this retrospective of experimental shorts by Austrian filmmaker Peter Tscherkassky. Titles date from 1981 through to the 1999 trailer for the Viennese Film Festival - Viennale. The films work through an experimentation with dissolves, double exposures, the ambiguity of light, found footage and the looping of vision and sound. Sound features heavily in Tscherkassky’s work and the principal composer here is Armin Schminkl. Schminkl also features as a subject for several films in the retrospective. Titles are as follows: Outerspace; The Arrival (L’Arrivee); Happy End; Parallel Space: interview; Tabula Rasa; Shot-Countershot; Kelimba; Manufraktur; Motion Picture; Urlaubsfilm; Freeze Frame; Liebesfilm; Erotique; Aderlab; Get Ready - Viennale ‘99 Trailer.
results.title_for_label: [Musterrolle: a compilation of short films by Peter Tscherkassky]
